documents.title: What should I do if the e-sign link shows an error?
documents.content:
Check the account stage first:
•	If at "Application Completed": The customer must authorize their debit card via the online portal at www.ticktockloans.com
•	If at "Card Declined": They need to reattempt verification via the portal
•	If at "Underwriting": The application is under review
•	If still at "e-sign": Test the link. If the issue persists, ask the customer to clear their cache and try again. Escalate with a screenshot if necessary.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What happens if the first repayment date is within a few days of the application date?
documents.content: You can select the customer's following payday; however, you must inform them of the additional cost, as daily interest will accrue during this period at a rate of 0.8% of the outstanding principal per day.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What if the customer has no additional income?
documents.content: They must still enter £00.00 in the additional income field, otherwise they will not be able to proceed with the application.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Customer Portal & Login Issues
documents.content: Go to www.ticktockloans.com, click 'Forgot Password,' and enter their email and surname exactly as it appears in CRM.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What causes login issues after a password reset?
documents.content: Usually due to extra spaces or case sensitivity in the email or password. Ask the customer to copy and paste the password from our email into the login page.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What should I do if the 'My Card' section is missing in the portal?
documents.content: Ask the customer to refresh the page—it should appear afterward.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: When can a customer be rolled back from Collections to Funds Sent?
documents.content: If they make the missed payment or set up a new arrangement.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: When should a customer be moved from Collections to a Payment Plan?
documents.content: If they make a payment or set up an arrangement while in M0, M1, M2, DMC, or Hold stages.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What types of schedules are available?
documents.content:
Payplan by Amounts (fixed monthly payments)
Payplan by Duration (based on number of months)
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What payment methods can be used in a new schedule?
documents.content: Manual (via phone or bank transfer) or Card (CPA payments).
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What details must be entered for a new payment plan?
documents.content: Repayment method, amount (£) or number of payments, first payment date, payment frequency, and interest settings.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Can the first or second payment in a plan be adjusted?
documents.content: Yes, this can be done via the 'Additional Info' section during schedule setup.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: When should interest continue during a payment plan?
documents.content: Only if the price CAP has not yet been reached.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: How does a customer evidence their income?
documents.content: By sending their most recent payslip or a bank statement showing salary credits within the last 30 days.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: The customer says they've never had to provide proof of income before. What should I say?
documents.content: Explain that, in line with our repeat lending policy, income verification is required. Without this, we cannot proceed with the application.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What email should I send when asking a customer to evidence income?
documents.content: Use Email ID 62 -- Payslip / Bank Statement email. Type this into the email dropdown—it will appear at the top.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What happens if the "Open Banking" task doesn't raise after the customer signs up with Plaid?
documents.content: Walk them through the process on the phone. Allow a minute for the task to generate. If it still doesn't appear, ask them to send in a bank statement covering the last 30 days.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Can I confirm the SMS code over the phone?
documents.content: Yes, but only if the customer is calling from the mobile number on record
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Can I confirm the email code over the phone?
documents.content: No. The customer must access the email themselves. This is part of our two-step verification and must not be bypassed.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Can I stay on the call while the customer agrees to the credit agreement?
documents.content: No. You must not remain on the call while the customer reads and agrees to the credit agreement and regulatory documents.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What is the Right to Withdraw (RTW) process?
documents.content:
The customer can withdraw from the agreement within 14 days of the loan being funded. This period begins the day after the loan is funded. Once a customer has withdrawn, they have 30 days to repay the balance. This balance will accrue daily interest at a rate of 0.8% per day, based on the outstanding principal.
You should set a repayment date within the 30-day period via the Accounts tab in the Schedule section. Once the loan has been settled, raise a "Customer Service -- Withdrawal from Agreement" task. After full RTW compliance, the loan entry will be removed from the customer's credit file with the credit reference agencies.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: I've received the transaction response: "Transaction Success" -- what does this mean?
documents.content: This means that the transaction verification or payment was successful. Either the payment has been taken, or the verification has completed as expected.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: I've received the transaction response: "Transaction declined by authorization system" -- what does this mean?
documents.content: This typically refers to R1: Revocation of Authorisation, meaning the cardholder has requested to stop all recurring payment transactions. You should contact the customer to confirm whether they have cancelled all transactions. This response applies to VISA
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: The customer says the application was made fraudulently and not by them. What should I do?
documents.content:
When taking the initial details of an alleged fraudulent application, make sure to record the following information on the system:
•	Contact telephone number
•	Email address
•	Whether they recognise or hold the current bank details on the account
If the customer does not recognise the bank account, advise them to report it to their bank and request an investigation into how the account was opened in their name. We will need a copy of the letter the bank issues once their investigation is complete before we can consider closing the account.
If the bank account does belong to the customer, we will still require written confirmation from the bank stating that fraudulent transactions occurred and were investigated. In such cases, we expect the bank to reimburse the customer, who can then return the funds to us. We will also require a letter from the bank in order to write off any remaining interest.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What is the Debt Respite Scheme?
documents.content:
The Debt Respite Scheme, also known as Breathing Space, is a UK government initiative that offers individuals temporary protection from creditors while they seek debt advice or mental health treatment.
There are two types:
•	Standard Breathing Space -- lasts for 60 days
•	Mental Health Crisis Breathing Space -- lasts for the duration of the treatment, plus an additional 30 days, even if this exceeds 60 days
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What stage should I use for an account under the Debt Respite Scheme?
documents.content:
Use On Hold -- 2 Months for a standard breathing space
Use On Hold -- Vulnerable Customer for a Mental Health breathing space

In both cases, make sure to add a task to review the account in 60 days. The Insolvency Service typically informs us when the hold expires.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Is interest added while the account is in Breathing Space?
documents.content: No. Interest, fees, and charges are frozen while the account is in Breathing Space.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Customer has joined a debt management company---what info do I need?
documents.content: The name of the DMC, reference number, and the date they joined.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What stage should I move an account to if the customer joins a DMC?
documents.content: Move the account to "On Hold -- Debt Management."
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Do I need to send the customer a "Repaid" email once the balance is cleared?
documents.content: No. The system automatically sends this when the balance reaches zero.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What should I check before saving a payment plan?
documents.content: Double-check all entered information, then save and confirm details with the customer.
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What should I do if a customer's portal isn't updating properly?
documents.content: Ask them to refresh the page or try using a different browser.
documents.source: Manual Entry

documents.title: What are the contact details for Tick Tock Loans?
documents.content:
•	Phone: 020 8090 8340
•	Address: 7 Berley Crescent, Gravesend, DA12 2AH
•	Website: www.ticktockloans.com
Email Addresses:
Customer Service: customerservice@ticktockloans.com
Collections: collections@ticktockloans.com
Complaints: complaints@ticktockloans.com
Underwriting: underwriting@ticktockloans.com
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: What are the contact details for Tick Tock Advance (MCA Product)?
documents.content:
Website: www.ticktockcredit.co.uk
Phone: 020 3838 2148
Email: customerservice@ticktockcredit.co.uk
documents.source: Tick Tock Loans Knowledge Base v1

documents.title: Right to Withdraw (RTW) Process
documents.content:
If a customer wishes to withdraw from their loan agreement, they must inform us within 14 days of the loan being funded. This 14-day period starts the day after the loan is funded.
The customer can notify us of their intention to withdraw either verbally or in writing.
The customer has 30 days from the date they notify us of their intention to withdraw to repay:
The amount borrowed, plus
The daily interest accrued up to the date the repayment is made.
Ask the customer to confirm the exact date they intend to make the repayment.
Create a new payment schedule for that date.
Set yourself a follow-up task on the same date to check whether the payment was made and follow up if necessary.
If the Customer Can’t Confirm a Date schedule the repayment for the 30th day after the withdrawal notification.
If the customer is unhappy with a card payment being scheduled, switch the payment method to bank transfer to avoid automated card collection attempts.
The balance will remain due, and the customer will continue to receive payment reminders as part of the usual communication cycle. If unpaid, the account will flow into the standard collections strategy.
documents.source: Manual Entry

documents.title: Interest Query
documents.content:
Process Overview

Refer to the customer’s original loan schedule and explain the Total Amount Payable (TAP) they agreed to at the start of their loan.
Let them know that this amount reflects what they would repay if all payments were made on time, with no changes to their repayment dates.
If the TAP has increased due to changes in payment behaviour, explain why:
Interest accrues daily at a rate of 0.8% on the outstanding principal.
Any missed payments, changes in payday, or reduced payments may lead to an increase in the total interest charged.
Reassure them that interest is capped at 100% of the amount borrowed — this is a rule set by our regulator, the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).
Help the customer understand how they can reduce their interest:

The more they pay, the less interest is charged, as the balance decreases.
Even nominal payments (small amounts) can help reduce the interest if made within the interest-charging period.
If the customer expresses frustration (e.g., “You’re ripping me off” or “You’re like loan sharks”), respond calmly and clearly:

We are a regulated lender, authorised by the FCA.
We follow all legal rules on interest and have clearly outlined the terms in the agreement the customer signed.
We do not charge more than the 100% cap, and customers have control over how much interest builds up by making timely or early payments.
Offer to help them explore ways to settle early or reduce their repayment burden.
documents.source: Manual Entry

documents.title: Fraud Process
documents.content:
Process Overview:

Customer confirms that the bank details are not theirs:

If a customer contacts us to say they didn’t apply for the loan — often after receiving a default notice or spotting it on their credit file — follow these steps:
Verify Identity & Cross-Check Details
Ask the customer to confirm their full name, email address, contact number, and bank account details.
Compare these to what’s recorded on the account.
Outcome Based on Matching Details
If the email, phone number, and bank details match:
This likely indicates the customer, or someone close to them, made the application.
The customer would usually remain liable.
If you’re uncertain, escalate to the Fraud Specialist – Zoe Quick.
If any details do not match, especially the bank details:
Record the customer's correct contact details in the system for follow-up.
Advise the customer to report the loan as fraudulent to the bank used on the application.
The bank must investigate and provide a written response confirming the findings.
Hold the Account
Place the account on hold for 30 days while waiting for bank confirmation.
After 30 days or upon receipt of the bank’s response, escalate to Zoe Quick for fraud investigation.
Customer Confirms All Details Are Correct – But Denies Applying

If the customer confirms that all details on the loan are correct, but insists they didn’t apply:
Advise Immediate External Reporting
Instruct the customer to report the incident to:
Their bank
Action Fraud
The police (to obtain a crime reference number)
Request Supporting Evidence
We require a letter from the bank confirming that the loan funds were deposited and withdrawn by a third party without the customer’s consent.
This confirmation must be in writing and clearly state that the transaction was fraudulent.
Fraud Outcome Handling

Once confirmed in writing:
The customer will be expected to repay the original loan amount (principal), since the funds were received.
The business will then write off any interest that accrued.
This aligns with our policy where fraud is proven and funds are reimbursed by the bank.
documents.source: Manual Entry
